pull.title: index: Change sync variables to use `std::chrono::steady_clock`
pull.body: This PR refactors the sync variables to use `std::chrono::steady_clock` as it is best suitable for measuring intervals.

rename.from: index: Change sync interval variables to std::chrono::seconds
rename.to: index, refactor: Change sync interval variables to std::chrono::seconds

events.body: You'll also have to change the title to explain the behavior change

events.message:
index, refactor: Change sync variables to use `std::chrono::steady_clock`

This refactors the sync variables to use `std::chrono::steady_clock`
as it is best suitable for measuring intervals.

rename.from: index, refactor: Change sync interval variables to std::chrono::seconds

events.body:

Also changed the PR title and description.

rename.to: index: Change sync variables to use `std::chrono::steady_clock`

comments.body:
```suggestion
            auto current_time{GetTime<std::chrono::seconds>()};
```
It is clear from the rhs what the type is.
Done in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25079/commits/626b636b193baae81a697febd41a712f94a8a702. Thanks for the suggestion.
Done in https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25079/commits/626b636b193baae81a697febd41a712f94a8a702. Thanks for the suggestion.

given that the clock is used to schedule things, an alternative would be to change this to a steady clock. This will behave better if the system clock is adjusted. However std::chrono::steady_clock is not mockable, which I think is fine in this context here.

```suggestion
            auto current_time{std::chrono::steady_clock::now()};
```

last_log_time should be of the same type.

`std::chrono::stead_clock::time_point`
I'm not very familiar with the `std::chrono::steady_clock` interface but I think https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/25079/commits/74a70ebea07ccbf5c7402f932b1880c499dd3ac0 does the trick.
